qas.question: What is able to prevent AA from being released from membranes?
The conversion of omega-6 DGLA to AA is able to help regulate which process?

answers.text: the production of the prostaglandins PGE1 and PGE2

qas.question: What kind of process is the conversion of DGLA to AA?
What is an example of a hormone other than insulin that is able to control the enzyme delta-5-desaturase?
What is the scientific name for cell division?

context: The conversion rate of omega-6 DGLA to AA largely determines <a1_0>the production of the prostaglandins PGE1 and PGE2<a1_0/>. <a0_0>Omega-3 EPA<a0_0/> prevents AA from being released from membranes, thereby skewing prostaglandin balance away from pro-inflammatory PGE2 (made from AA) toward anti-inflammatory PGE1 (made from DGLA). Moreover, the conversion (<a2_0>desaturation<a2_0/>) of DGLA to AA is controlled by the enzyme delta-5-desaturase, which in turn is controlled by hormones such as insulin (up-regulation) and <a3_0>glucagon<a3_0/> (down-regulation). The amount and type of carbohydrates consumed, along with some types of amino acid, can influence processes involving insulin, glucagon, and other hormones; therefore, the ratio of omega-3 versus omega-6 has wide effects on general health, and specific effects on immune function and inflammation, and <a4_0>mitosis<a4_0/> (i.e., cell division).
